skills.name: Shade unit fractions when part of a shape
Identify unit fractions when part of a shape
Shade non-unit fractions when part of a shape
Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape
Identify equivalent fractions when presented as shapes or objects

explanations.A: In this diagram, one out of every three equally-sized rectangles is shaded. Do any of the other diagrams follow the same pattern?
explanations.B: In this diagram, two out of six or one out of every three equally-sized rectangles is shaded. Do any of the other diagrams follow the same pattern?
explanations.C: In this diagram, three out of nine or one out of every three equally-sized rectangles is shaded. Do any of the other diagrams follow the same pattern?
explanations.D: In Diagrams A, B and C, 1 out of every 3 equally-sized parts are shaded = ⅓. In Diagram D, 1 out of every 2 equally-sized parts are shaded so D is the odd one out.

explanations.A: In this diagram, three out of every four equally-sized rectangles are shaded. Do any of the other diagrams follow the same pattern?
explanations.B: In this diagram, six out of eight or three out of every four equally-sized rectangles are shaded. Do any of the other diagrams follow the same pattern?
explanations.C: In Diagrams A, B and D, 3 out of every 4 equally-sized parts are shaded = ¾. In Diagram C, 2 out of every 3 equally-sized parts are shaded so C is the odd one out.
explanations.D: In this diagram, twelve out of sixteen or three out of every four equally-sized rectangles are shaded. Do any of the other diagrams follow the same pattern?

explanations.A: All the other diagrams show one out of four equally-sized parts shaded which equals ¼. But in this diagram, the parts are not equally sized so this diagram does not show ¼ shaded.
explanations.B: In this diagram, one out of four equally-sized rectangles is shaded which equals ¼. But we need a diagram which does NOT show ¼ shaded.
explanations.C: In this diagram, one out of four equally-sized rectangles is shaded which equals ¼. But we need a diagram which does NOT show ¼ shaded.
explanations.D: We can split the large white rectangle on the right into two more of the smaller rectangles. This will give us one shaded part out of four equally-sized parts which equals ¼. But we need a diagram which does NOT show ¼ shaded.

explanations.A: In this diagram, one out of ten equally-sized rectangles is shaded which equals ⅒. But we need a diagram which does NOT show ⅒ shaded.
explanations.B: In this diagram, one out of ten equally-sized rectangles is shaded which equals ⅒. But we need a diagram which does NOT show ⅒ shaded.
explanations.C: We can split the large white rectangle on the left into five of the smaller rectangles. This will give us one shaded part out of ten equally-sized parts which equals ⅒. But we need a diagram which does NOT show ⅒ shaded.
explanations.D: All the other diagrams show one out of ten equally sized parts shaded which equals ⅒. But in this diagram, the parts are not equally sized so this diagram does not show ⅒ shaded.

explanations.A: Try splitting the larger rectangles into equally-sized, smaller rectangles that are the same shape and size as the shaded rectangle.
explanations.B: We do have one shaded rectangle but how many rectangles of this size fit into the whole shape? Our answer will be a fraction out of the total number of equally-sized rectangles.
explanations.C: I can see why you might think that because we can see four rectangles and one is shaded. But we need the parts to be equally-sized. Can you split the whole shape into equally-sized rectangles?
explanations.D: We can split the whole shape into 8 equally-sized, smaller rectangles that are the same size and shape as the shaded rectangle. This will give us one shaded part out of 8 equally-sized parts = ⅛.

explanations.A: We can split the whole shape into 12 equally-sized, smaller rectangles that are the same size and shape as the shaded rectangle. This will give us one shaded part out of 12 equally-sized parts = 1/12.
explanations.B: I can see why you might think that because we can see five rectangles and one is shaded. But we need the parts to be equally-sized. Can you split the whole shape into equally-sized rectangles?
explanations.C: We do have one shaded rectangle but how many rectangles of this size fit into the whole shape? Our answer will be a fraction out of the total number of equally-sized rectangles.
explanations.D: Try splitting the larger rectangles into equally-sized, smaller rectangles that are the same shape and size as the shaded rectangle.

explanations.A: In this diagram, 2 out of 8 equally-sized rectangles are shaded = 2/8. But we need a diagram which does NOT show 2/8 shaded.
explanations.B: In this diagram, 2 out of 8 equally-sized rectangles are shaded = 2/8. But we need a diagram which does NOT show 2/8 shaded.
explanations.C: All the other diagrams show 2 out of 8 equally-sized parts shaded = 2/8. But in this diagram, the parts are not equally sized so this diagram does not show 2/8 shaded.
explanations.D: We can split the large white rectangle on the right into 4 of the smaller rectangles. This will give us 2 shaded parts out of 8 equally-sized parts = 2/8. But we need a diagram which does NOT show 2/8 shaded.

explanations.A: We can split the large white rectangle on the right into 6 of the smaller rectangles. We can also split the medium rectangle above the shaded rectangles into 3 of the smaller rectangles. This will give us 3 shaded parts out of 12 equally-sized parts = 3/12. But we need a diagram which does NOT show 3/12 shaded.
explanations.B: In this diagram, 3 out of 12 equally-sized rectangles are shaded = 3/12. But we need a diagram which does NOT show 3/12 shaded.
explanations.C: In this diagram, 3 out of 12 equally-sized rectangles are shaded = 3/12. But we need a diagram which does NOT show 3/12 shaded.
explanations.D: All the other diagrams show 3 out of 12 equally-sized parts shaded = 3/12. But in this diagram, the parts are not equally sized so this diagram does not show 3/12 shaded.

explanations.A: Almost! We want the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded yellow but you have given the fraction that is not shaded.
explanations.B: We do have 3 shaded rectangles but how many rectangles are there in total? Our answer will be a fraction out of the total number of equally-sized rectangles.
explanations.C: Not quite. You have used the number of unshaded rectangles as your denominator. We want the fraction of the whole shape so we need to count all the equally-sized rectangles in the whole shape.
explanations.D: The rectangle has been split into 10 equally-sized, smaller rectangles and 3 of them are shaded. So the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded is 3/10.

explanations.A: The rectangle has been split into 10 x 10 = 100 equally-sized, smaller rectangles and 10 + 10 + 7 = 27 of them are shaded. So the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded is 27/100.
explanations.B: Not quite. You have used the number of unshaded rectangles as your denominator. We want the fraction of the whole shape so we need to count all the equally-sized rectangles in the whole shape.
explanations.C: We do have 27 shaded rectangles but how many rectangles are there in total? Our answer will be a fraction out of the total number of equally-sized rectangles.
explanations.D: Almost! We want the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded yellow but you have given the fraction that is not shaded.
